importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 18, 2025, and discusses current developments in US manufacturing under President Donald Trump’s trade policies, particularly regarding tariffs and their economic effects.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The article references the historical context of US manufacturing, noting a shift from mass production in the 1990s to current challenges involving automation and skilled labor, with Steinway's factory having operated continuously since 1873.

keyTakeAways: Steinway & Sons is a rare example of successful US manufacturing that relies on skilled craftsmanship rather than mass production.
The company maintains high prices for its pianos (ranging from $90,000 to $200,000) due to premium quality and legacy brand value, enabling sustainability despite high costs.
Despite Trump’s trade war and tariffs on steel, aluminum, and copper, Steinway has not been significantly affected due to domestic sourcing and focus on quality.
The company faces challenges including a potential shortage of Sitka spruce lumber from Alaska and a shrinking pool of skilled workers.
Steinway's long-standing operation in Astoria, Queens, is due to the irreplaceable skill set of its craftsmen, who are trained over generations and essential to maintaining quality and continuity.
The article suggests that traditional craftsmanship and quality-focused manufacturing may be more viable in the US than low-cost, volume-based production under current economic conditions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores how Steinway & Sons, a 150-year-old piano manufacturer in Queens, New York, remains a rare success story in American manufacturing by relying on skilled craftsmanship and domestic production rather than mass manufacturing. Despite President Trump’s trade war and rising input costs from tariffs on steel, aluminum, and copper, Steinway thrives due to its high pricing, quality, and long-standing workforce. The company’s production process—spanning 11 months and involving only four to five pianos per day—relies on a unique, irreplaceable pool of skilled artisans, many of whom have trained over generations. While global supply challenges, such as limited Sitka spruce from Alaska, pose risks, the company’s commitment to quality and human skill has ensured its continued presence in the US manufacturing sector, offering a model for how traditional, artisan-based production can succeed in an era of automation and economic uncertainty.
title: How a company from the Gilded Age could be the future of US manufacturing
